math_problem.A442: For non-negative real numbers $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n$ which satisfy $x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n = 1$, find the largest possible value of $\sum_{j = 1}^{n} (x_j^{4} - x_j^{5})$. Instead of finding the largest possible value of the sum of fourth powers minus fifth powers over non-negative reals summing to one, simply find $e = k + \frac{24083}{12}$, where $k$ is the largest possible value of $\sum_{j=1}^n (x_j^4 - x_j^5)$.

math_problem.A3957:
Consider those functions $ f: \mathbb{N} \mapsto \mathbb{N}$ which satisfy the condition
\[ f(m \plus{} n) \geq f(m) \plus{} f(f(n)) \minus{} 1
\]
for all $ m,n \in \mathbb{N}.$ Find all possible values of $ f(2007).$

[i]Author: Nikolai Nikolov, Bulgaria[/i]

A442: Mathematics -> Algebra -> Algebra -> Equations and Inequalities
Mathematics -> Calculus -> Differential Calculus -> Applications of Derivatives
